@Ken'ichi Ohmichi, so, at the moment, the nova Hyper-V driver doesn't wait for the neutron ports to become active before starting the VM (like libvirt driver does, if it is configured to do so). Which means that the instance can become active before the neutron port becomes active.

Even if the wait can be implemented in the nova Hyper-V driver, it would only solve the issue for the master branch; the stable branches would still be effected.

Furthermore, I've seen this same traceback mentioned in the commit message associated with multiple bugs in openstack, which were "fixed", but the issue persists.

Finally, I've been doing some debugging, and I've noticed that the port list returned from neutron would have ports still "building", even if the ports have been bound on the compute node, resulting in the mentioned error. Typically, waiting a few seconds and refetching the port list will result in success, the ports will be active.

If this merges, a lot of random failures will be reduced from the Hyper-V CI.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2016-11-09 01:59:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Thanks for your explanation,

 > @Ken'ichi Ohmichi, so, at the moment, the nova Hyper-V driver
 > doesn't wait for the neutron ports to become active before
 > starting the VM (like libvirt driver does, if it is configured to do so).

So that means API abstraction layer doesn't work on Nova, I feel because the behaviors are different on backend hypervisors.
I think that should be fixed on Nova side and that could be backported into stable branches also."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2016-11-09 02:14:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Some related conversation:

 18:00 (oomichi) mriedem: hi, can you take a look at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/383049 ?    That seems different API behaviors between backend hypervisors
 18:03 (mriedem) oomichi: that's because the hyper-v driver doesn't implement the same wait code that the libvirt driver does, which is waiting for neutron to ack that the vifs are plugged and the ports are active, which then continues the spawn() operation in the virt driver before the vm_state goes to ACTIVE
 18:04 (mriedem) i guess that's noted in the bug report:
 18:04 (mriedem) "Currently, the nova Hyper-V driver does not wait for neutron vif plug  events (or, in case of other drivers, nova-compute can be configured not  to wait for neutron vif plug events),"
 18:04 (mriedem) ideally the hyperv driver would implement that wait code fo the vif plugged event
 18:04 (oomichi) mriedem: yeah, I agree with you
 18:05 (oomichi) mriedem: the bug is registered as tempest bug anyways ;)
 18:05 (mriedem) clearly, CLEARLY, this is all tempest's fault. :)
 18:06 (mriedem) so, as claudiu pointed out in the review, and bug report, you can configure nova-compute to not wait for the vif plugged events, but if you're using neutron and have a virt driver that supports that, i don't know why you'd do that
 18:06 (oomichi) mriedem: I cannot vote on that :)
 18:06 (mriedem) but that is a configuration change on the compute that impacts the behavior of the api
 18:07 (mriedem) so for libvirt the tests are probably working fine b/c when we get to that point the ports are already active b/c we've waited for the server to be active, which waited for the ports to be active
 18:07 (oomichi) mriedem: yeah, actually that seems difficult to make API behaviors same between drivers
 18:08 (mriedem) it's probably not unreasonable to expect the client to wait for the port status to be active before operations, like associating a floating IP to the port, can be performed on it
 18:08 (mriedem) what would happen if we associated the floating IP to the server via neutron APIs rather than the proxy APIs in nova? would neutron require the port to be active?
 18:12 (oomichi) hopefully, all cilents could be waiting for the port status as the patch, but actually it is difficult to expect that because tempest doesn't do that.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2016-11-09 02:16:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)

First, the hyper-v driver supports neutron and runs CI testing with it, and therefore it should implement the wait code for the vif plugged event to come back to nova-compute before completing the spawn() method in the virt driver and marking the server as ACTIVE. Any virt driver supporting neutron, which is all of them now, should implement that, and the vif plugging thing in nova-compute should really be non-optional if using neutron, the only configurable thing should be the timeout.

Having said that, as noted in the bug report nova has proxy APIs for associating a floating IP to a port on a server, but that can be done via neutron APIs. Alex Xu actually has a spec up for nova to deprecate that proxy API in nova, which would make you use the neutron APIs to associate a floating IP to a port that's associated to a server - it's rather indirect, but it's possible. So the question I'd have there is, would the neutron API require that the port status be ACTIVE before you could associate the floating IP? Because if so, then this is probably a valid change to make regardless of the nova virt drivers implementing the vif plugged event callback or not."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2016-11-09 02:19:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I also agree with Ken'ichi that "fixing" this in Tempest is masking over the API usability issue in Nova when using the hyper-v driver. So I definitely think we need to close that gap on the nova side regardless of whether or not this change is made in Tempest.'}, {'account_id': 12604, 'date': '2016-11-15 13:39:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2016-11-20 09:28:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Why is the VM booting if the port status is not ACTIVE?'}, {'account_id': 7787, 'date': '2016-11-20 09:31:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

oh, i see in the backlog now. To answer Matt's question, neutron doesn't care if associating a floating IP with a port in the DOWN status.

I don't think this is something that should be fixed on the tempest side. HyperV shouldn't boot a VM if it hasn't received the vif callback...

There are lots of bugs with networks, security groups, dhcp entries, DNS entries, etc possibly being in an incomplete state if the VM just starts up without waiting for that callback."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2016-11-21 23:00:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-2

It is nice to keep current Tempest code for detecting this kind of bugs and finding the valid fixing way.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-23 15:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Verified-1

commit_message:
wait for port status to be ACTIVE

Some tests are failing on the Hyper-V CI due to the
fact that tempest does not wait for the neutron
ports to be come active. All ports that are not active
are ignored, leading to failed tests [1].

Waiting for the ports to become active solves the issue.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/584712/

Closes-Bug: #1631872

Change-Id: Iab2e4b22d80d16b48fc28568b8737b2432a6595c

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

(1 comment)

Thank for this work!

The change looks mostly good, only the commit message is incorrect.

Since you're updating the creds_client, and it doesn't have any unit test on the create user method, would you mind adding a couple of tests to verify the list of parameters passed to the create_user for v2 and v3?

Another concern I have is that we do not really test this code path in the gate anywhere. I added support for a non-default domain to make the tests more portable, but since it's not tested, it may bit rot in future. Would you mind setting up an experimental job which provisions test users in a non-default domain?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-12-16 15:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Verified+1

It seems the params are a little duplicated,
how about:
class CredsClient(object):
    def create_user(self, username, password, project, email, domain_id=None):
        params = {'name': username,
                  'password': password,
                  self.project_id_param: project['id'],
                  'email': email}
        if domain_id is not None:
            params['domain_id'] = domain_id
    ......

class V3CredsClient(CredsClient):
    def create_user(self, username, password, project, email, domain_id=None):
        if domain_id is None:
            domain_id = self.creds_domain
        return super(V3CredsClient, self).create_user(username, password, project, email, domain_id)

And no change in V2CredsClient"}, {'account_id': 23771, 'date': '2017-01-10 14:37:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

> It seems the params are a little duplicated,

 > class CredsClient(object):
 > def create_user(self, username, password, project, email,
 > domain_id=None):
 > params = {'name': username,
 > 'password': password,
 > self.project_id_param: project['id'],
 > 'email': email}
 > if domain_id is not None:
 > params['domain_id'] = domain_id
 > ......

 > class V3CredsClient(CredsClient):
 > def create_user(self, username, password, project, email,
 > domain_id=None):

 > domain_id = self.creds_domain
 > return super(V3CredsClient, self).create_user(username, password,
 > project, email, domain_id)
 > 
 > And no change in V2CredsClient

I think your optimization conflicts with Jordan Pittier code optimization. I suppose we double use the same params for child and parent classes."}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2017-01-11 01:00:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: -Code-Review

@morfy, I don't really think my opinion conflict with Jordan:)
Usually a code optimization will be based on the previous patch, but if you look from the very begining, maybe you will have another design:)

I am OK to keep current implementation, current one also is simple to read the code.

commit_message:
Fix for domain_id in V3 keystone authorization

In case of using V3 keystone authorization with Default domain name,
which id not default, create_user failed, with error "Could not find
domain: default". So, this patch add domain_id field to the keystone
request and authorization continues normally.

Closes-Bug: #1613819

Change-Id: I6c4dd908658609e7c082a8234af33f812b8afd06

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-24 09:01:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix fip association issue when multi servers are created

In test_resize_volume_backed_server_confirm, when connect_method=floating,
because create_test_server doesn't use validatable=True and
validation_resources=validation_resources, so the created server hasn't any
floating ip associated to it, and so the following self.get_server_ip(server,
validation_resources) just refers to other server (the one created in setUp),
this is an amusing hidden error.

This is to move the setup_validation_fip from create_test_server to
get_server_ip, that is, one floating ip can be used for different servers,
so we should associate the floating ip to the server when the server is ready
to ssh, while not when the server is created.

Besides, compute.create_test_server will no longer have the limitation that
"multiple pingable or sshable servers will not be supported", because all other
validation resources can be shared except floating ip, such as keypair,
security group. And as to floating ip, we will associate it to the server which
is ready to ssh.

Change-Id: I2cd55b151f3bbf5d765e65c8d29578b9f0a7d698
Closes-Bug: #1751418

commit_message:
Fix fip association issue when multi servers are created

In test_resize_volume_backed_server_confirm, when connect_method=floating,
because create_test_server doesn't use validatable=True and
validation_resources=validation_resources, so the created server hasn't any
floating ip associated to it, and so the following self.get_server_ip(server,
validation_resources) just refers to other server (the one created in setUp),
this is an amusing hidden error.

This is to move the setup_validation_fip from create_test_server to
get_server_ip, that is, one floating ip can be used for different servers,
so we should associate the floating ip to the server when the server is ready
to ssh, while not when the server is created.

Besides, compute.create_test_server will no longer have the limitation that
"multiple pingable or sshable servers will not be supported", because all other
validation resources can be shared except floating ip, such as keypair,
security group. And as to floating ip, we will associate it to the server one
at a time.

Change-Id: I2cd55b151f3bbf5d765e65c8d29578b9f0a7d698
Closes-Bug: #1751418

commit_message:
Object test not cleaning up containers.

The below test will not clean up containers

tempest.api.object_storage.test_object_services.PublicObjectTest
tempest.api.object_storage.test_container_acl_negative.ObjectACLsNegativeTest

This patch set will directly call the delete function.

Change-Id: Ic09089fbd488825ba85099171d97bb31921f4993
Closes-Bug: #1769005

commit_message:
Move value of notifications in TestSwiftTelemetry to config.py

Currently the value of notifications wait&sleep is hard coding which is
not allowed to change them by config. We should move them to
TelemetryGroup in config.py.

Change-Id: Ic5c4b036ac111ad7a7326fd1caa7460659a3026e
Closes-Bug: #1489772

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-15 16:59:18.000000000', 'message': 'Fix --limit with commas

Kayobe allows specifying a --limit argument, which is passed through to
Ansible. In some cases we wish to add an intersection with a group. This
allows us to reuse playbooks for the seed, overcloud etc.

For example, the lvm.yml playbook specifies a host list of
seed-hypervisor:seed:overcloud. When executed as part of a kayobe
overcloud host configure command, Kayobe passes a limit of overcloud. If
the user specifies a --limit argument, this gets intersected with the
overcloud limit: host1:&overcloud.

The problem happens if the user specifies multiple parts to the host
pattern in their limit using a comma, e.g. host1,host2. This results in
host1,host2:&overcloud. Ansible ignores the colon, and treats this as
host1 or host2:&overcloud.

The solution is to use a comma to join the patterns if the user has used
a comma: host1,host2,&overcloud

Change-Id: Ibe42fa372c6fa0c539d2c2b0e238601286dc213d
Story: 2008255
Task: 41111
(cherry picked from commit 017b092df70706177c542c3a3cab3f9d0a75e5c2)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix --limit with commas

Kayobe allows specifying a --limit argument, which is passed through to
Ansible. In some cases we wish to add an intersection with a group. This
allows us to reuse playbooks for the seed, overcloud etc.

For example, the lvm.yml playbook specifies a host list of
seed-hypervisor:seed:overcloud. When executed as part of a kayobe
overcloud host configure command, Kayobe passes a limit of overcloud. If
the user specifies a --limit argument, this gets intersected with the
overcloud limit: host1:&overcloud.

The problem happens if the user specifies multiple parts to the host
pattern in their limit using a comma, e.g. host1,host2. This results in
host1,host2:&overcloud. Ansible ignores the colon, and treats this as
host1 or host2:&overcloud.

The solution is to use a comma to join the patterns if the user has used
a comma: host1,host2,&overcloud

Change-Id: Ibe42fa372c6fa0c539d2c2b0e238601286dc213d
Story: 2008255
Task: 41111
(cherry picked from commit 017b092df70706177c542c3a3cab3f9d0a75e5c2)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-09 10:22:00.000000000', 'message': "Workaround problem with deepcopy of the regex object in python 3.6

Oslo.policy in version 3.6.2 introduced deepcopy of the rule objects
during initialize of the policy.
It breaks Neutron when running on Python 3.6 or older due to bug [1]
because in the FieldCheck class, which is defined in our repo we are
using regex and that regex can't be deepcopied properly.

This patch workarounds that problem by implementing custom __deepcopy__
method in that class for python 3.6 and older.

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue10076

Related-Bug: #1913718
Change-Id: Ib05c4b60ac06facd5d6f31668af3ab51b854d543
"}]
commit_message:
Workaround problem with deepcopy of the regex object in python 3.6

Oslo.policy in version 3.6.2 introduced deepcopy of the rule objects
during initialize of the policy.
It breaks Neutron when running on Python 3.6 or older due to bug [1]
because in the FieldCheck class, which is defined in our repo we are
using regex and that regex can't be deepcopied properly.

This patch workarounds that problem by implementing custom __deepcopy__
method in that class for python 3.6 and older.

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue10076

Related-Bug: #1913718
Change-Id: Ib05c4b60ac06facd5d6f31668af3ab51b854d543

subject: Fix Barbican API log config
messages: [{'account_id': 30523, 'date': '2021-02-08 19:12:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2021-02-08 20:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2021-02-09 10:12:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-08 19:12:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix Barbican API log config

There are a few issues fixed here:

- The Barbican API service doesn't set a log file, so all the Barbican API
  service logs go to loadwsgi.py.log by default.
- The logs in loadwsgi.py.log are not ingested properly by Fluentd.
- uWSGI logs go to barbican-api.log. This would normally be used as the log
  file for the Barbican API service logs.

This patch makes the following changes to address the above issues:

- All uWSGI logs (from the Emperor and Vassals) go to barbican_api_uwsgi_access.log
  Although these logs aren't strictly all access logs, this follows the existing
  pattern for WSGI logs.
- The Barbican API service logs are written to barbican-api.log instead of
  loadwsgi.py.log. This follows the pattern used by other OpenStack services.
- Fluentd is configured to parse the Barbican API service logs as it would with
  other OpenStack Python services.

Change-Id: I6d03fa8c81c52b6f061514a836bbd15bb6639aaf
Closes-Bug: #1891343
"}]
commit_message:
Fix Barbican API log config

There are a few issues fixed here:

- The Barbican API service doesn't set a log file, so all the Barbican API
  service logs go to loadwsgi.py.log by default.
- The logs in loadwsgi.py.log are not ingested properly by Fluentd.
- uWSGI logs go to barbican-api.log. This would normally be used as the log
  file for the Barbican API service logs.

This patch makes the following changes to address the above issues:

- All uWSGI logs (from the Emperor and Vassals) go to barbican_api_uwsgi_access.log
  Although these logs aren't strictly all access logs, this follows the existing
  pattern for WSGI logs.
- The Barbican API service logs are written to barbican-api.log instead of
  loadwsgi.py.log. This follows the pattern used by other OpenStack services.
- Fluentd is configured to parse the Barbican API service logs as it would with
  other OpenStack Python services.

Change-Id: I6d03fa8c81c52b6f061514a836bbd15bb6639aaf
Closes-Bug: #1891343

There are a few issues fixed here:

- The Barbican API service doesn't set a log file, so all the Barbican API
  service logs go to loadwsgi.py.log by default.
- The logs in loadwsgi.py.log are not ingested properly by Fluentd.
- uWSGI logs go to barbican-api.log. This would normally be used as the log
  file for the Barbican API service logs.

This patch makes the following changes to address the above issues:

- All uWSGI logs (from the Emperor and Vassals) go to barbican_api_uwsgi_access.log
  Although these logs aren't strictly all access logs, this follows the existing
  pattern for WSGI logs.
- The Barbican API service logs are written to barbican-api.log instead of
  loadwsgi.py.log. This follows the pattern used by other OpenStack services.
- Fluentd is configured to parse the Barbican API service logs as it would with

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: I64f3ddcdfb21d69ae8a6fc7abaeddee2a9289792

commit_message:
Use OOB inspection to fetch MACs for IB inspection

This change adds get_mac_addresses call to the ManagementInterface which will
be used by both out-of-band inspection and in-band inspection with
ironic-inspector. This will remove the necessity of manually defining MAC
addresses for nodes and/or enabling IPMI functionality on Redfish-based
systems.

Change-Id: I11c93de2ba8c6c952394856ab828989346377766
Story: 2008038

commit_message:
Allow both DEFAULT/dhcp_domain and api/dhcp_domain to be set

Partial revert of If6a26527a737a7184ebddd5b4bc346d64827e9e3 to allow
both/either config option to be used until it is clear what nova will
take.

Related-bug: #1903908
Change-Id: I98fe83e0c245388944529cd19b5e2bbed134e855

commit_message:
Use OOB inspection to fetch MACs for IB inspection

This change adds get_mac_addresses call to the ManagementInterface which will
be used by both out-of-band inspection and in-band inspection with
ironic-inspector. This will remove the necessity of manually defining MAC
addresses for nodes and/or enabling IPMI functionality on Redfish-based
systems.

Change-Id: I3debcd1f32a2627dafd8456ec73a71fc7c402ebb
Story: 2008038
Task: 40699

commit_message:
Use OOB inspection to fetch MACs for IB inspection

This change adds get_mac_addresses call to the ManagementInterface which will
be used by both out-of-band inspection and in-band inspection with
ironic-inspector. This will remove the necessity of manually defining MAC
addresses for nodes and/or enabling IPMI functionality on Redfish-based
systems.

Change-Id: I11c93de2ba8c6c952394856ab828989346377766
Story: 2008038

commit_message:
Add haproxy_*_service variables

This aims to ease override of the specific service listen port or other
haproxy frontend/backend setting without override of all backends.

Change-Id: I051539fc3bbd3bfcddc30048348c571dd6a5c7e1
(cherry picked from commit 65a8c2413e1e8f91fd6d712cb84af2ab01784299)

commit_message:
Set the Nova availability zone different from volume az

The review allows related non-scenario tests
when Nova availability zone don't match the
volume availability zone. This configuration
might be used for the DCN compute-only environment
when edge sites haven't storage.

Change-Id: Icff9d1b0be927c5d3aced4394b42867c553a4e97

commit_message:
Do not prepare upstream repos for distro jobs

Since we don't build from source, we don't need to clone and prepare
upstream services' repos for distro jobs.

Change-Id: Ie58167c4bc940eb5b5d2887421212eb2ce97fb8d

commit_message:
Adds additional exception handling to credential provider

Adds additional handling to the PreProvisionedCredentialProvider
to handle the case where the os-networks extension is not
enabled.

Change-Id: I73cd35e04d72a96d6a3c3f8e85a2754fe16eeef6
Closes-Bug: 1600349

subject: Not delete an external network during tearDown

commit_message:
Not delete an external network during tearDown

When finished the testcases in test_auto_allocate_network, an
external network will be deleted in tearDown process, this will
fail if any IP is allocated in the network before. Then the
error happens. This patch make only delete the network owned
by the current tenant.

Change-Id: I39105c47febd11da27945ad690437bd7d2142167
Closes-Bug: #1677136

commit_message:
Add verification of show_password to test_change_server_password

We have a bug in nova where the password is not saved to the metadata
when the server's password is changed via the API. This adds
verification of the fix and will help catch regressions in the future.

Related-Bug: #1748544

Depends-On: Id5ff7527a687bf285158a70022110863b48b8495

Change-Id: Id2318e69708fc7457ca4980340b66a6bad3bc947

commit_message:
Remove deprecated AMI image file opts

This commit removes the deprecated config options for specifying AMI
image file locations. These options were deprecated in change
I8a6ee167384c8a2d17905db3a4061c06398980ad. The fallback mechanism using
these options is also removed, and the docs are updated to not mention
them anymore.

Depends-On: Ic276cbbb91aaf73ba44e588a607338b93d056da8
Change-Id: Icd1c0fe5c42738faf37302752fb3b7495efcf416
Closes-Bug: #1393881

So while I appreciate the intent here. The tasks api in glance is kind of an odd duck and isn't really universally used or exposed. There are also significant interop and user interaction issues with it. One of Glance's biggest priorities this cycle is to rework their api to fix these issues, you can see the spec discussion on this here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232371/

I think considering this we really don't want to add tempest tests for this api. I'm marking this as -2 to indicate this. 

This has also been raised on the ML by the glance PTL as something that we really shouldn't be testing:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-December/081770.html"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-03-04 05:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

commit_message:
Add test for glance's tasks API

Added new test for below glance's tasks APIs,

1. Create task
2. List task
3. Get task

Closes-Bug: #1484511
Change-Id: I3d40bde5c71447c91e5f6e63de6d5b355e6c5f98

commit_message:
Fix cases regarding to DHCP port operation.

When number of dhcp ports excess max_fixed_ips_per_port, a dhcp resync will be triggered.
DHCP port is not a tenant port. It means DHCP port is not a tenant resource.
So that - We should not restrict operations regarding DHCP port with admin user.
        - Operations of DHCP port from non-admin user should be forbidden.

Change-Id: I3fc3d3f37faf04ea8bfe720019a758326cf6b8ff
Closes-Bug: #1427015
Depends-On: Iaa9ed6949383ba6a7ce0b3ffd9dcced663126317

[{'account_id': 20424, 'date': '2016-02-14 07:45:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2016-02-14 07:45:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 20424, 'date': '2016-02-14 09:10:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-02-14 10:09:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-02-14 07:45:19.000000000', 'message': "Fixed bug with url building

The requested volume ID contains the hash tag, which makes the request
URL contain a 'fragment identifier'.
Some backend WSGI servers might cut this part and pass it in a different
environment variable.
Conceptually this is a bad practice.

Removing the hash tag from volume get, and volume delete.

Change-Id: I5b5849779a5fa5a6422cdeeb704131c292bd64a7
"}, {'created': '2016-02-14 09:10:06.000000000', 'message': "Fixed bug with url building

The requested volume ID contains the hash tag, which makes the request
URL contain a 'fragment identifier'.
Some backend WSGI servers might cut this part and pass it in a different
environment variable.
Conceptually this is a bad practice.

Removing the hash tag from volume get, and volume delete.

Change-Id: I5b5849779a5fa5a6422cdeeb704131c292bd64a7
Closes-bug: 1545407
"}, {'created': '2016-02-29 08:42:08.000000000', 'message': "Fixed bug with url building

The requested volume ID contains special characters such as hash '#' or precent '%'.

The hash tag makes the request URL contain a 'fragment identifier'.
Some backend WSGI servers might cut this part and pass it in a different
environment variable.
Conceptually this is a bad practice.

Regarding with RFC3986 percent character '%' must be followed by the two
hexadecimal digits. In other cases WSGI server can reject such request.

Replacing special characters in volume get, and volume delete with numerical characters.

Change-Id: I5b5849779a5fa5a6422cdeeb704131c292bd64a7
Closes-bug: 1545407
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed bug with url building

The requested volume ID contains special characters such as hash '#' or precent '%'.

The hash tag makes the request URL contain a 'fragment identifier'.
Some backend WSGI servers might cut this part and pass it in a different
environment variable.
Conceptually this is a bad practice.

Regarding with RFC3986 percent character '%' must be followed by the two
hexadecimal digits. In other cases WSGI server can reject such request.

Replacing special characters in volume get, and volume delete with numerical characters.

Change-Id: I5b5849779a5fa5a6422cdeeb704131c292bd64a7
Closes-bug: 1545407

commit_message:
remove order dependency for assert

Since the order in which we receive the allowed address pair doesn't matter,
removing the order dependency in _update_port_with_address method.

Change-Id: I319e154887566888ac350935fd8529177aa90e90
Closes-Bug: 1594633

commit_message:
Add test to verify ironic multitenancy

* Create two tenants with own networks.
* Boot 2 baremetal instances in the same network of
  the first tenant and check if they are L2-connected.
* Boot 2 baremetal instances in the different tenants
  and check if they are L2-isolated.

Change-Id: Ia76b7234e0ffce1b00fcc549f12054f84acc36e4
Closes-Bug: 1520230
Depends-On: Iaa787d6f0b643affd4c4666f654a5f7d8b37d2a3

subject: Add limit and detail optional cases for node list

Add limit and detail optional cases for node list

Add limit and detail optional test cases for
ironic node list api.

Change-Id: I6d8558667e561d77360e2d8043f57acc88594ce6
Closes-Bug: #1415341

Why not to create to option with multiple roles ?
Why not to name the option as user_roles ?'}, {'account_id': 14394, 'date': '2016-04-18 12:52:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@afazekas: It may be feasible that an operator considers having multiple roles comprise a default 'Member' of a project, I'm not sure I see the value it that though - do you have a use case in mind? It would simplify the code slightly, but make it differ from other default role declarations in this class.

The caveat is that if it were changed to a list of member_roles, ALL need to be present for a user match to occur in hash_list.

This may be confusing if specifying the following, where both member role names are used interchangeably(but not together) as various OpenStack projects do: member_roles = ['Member', '_member_']"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2016-05-09 14:21:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The history of the `member` role and its current usage is confusing regardless what we are doing. The current authZ system is far far smarter than just be able to recognize membership.

IMHO we should not use the member named role for generic users, we should use a 'user' named role as it was mentioned in the openstack docs. IMHO the shipped default policy.json files should contain the 'user' named role explicitly in all project. (I am planning to send an e-mail about this since long..)

Splitting the 'user' roles to `smaller ones` makes more sense when you trust/delegate a roles to another user.
I am not sure about how popular are these options nowadays.

Looks like the current code would need some more reshaping if we really want switch `smaller` roles anyway, so I will not block this change just because of this. We have abstraction leakage issues regardless to the new option is an array or scalar ..

Do we really want to use the `member` term today (2016) instead of the `user` or `default` or `default_user` ?"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2016-05-11 09:12:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I still don't like the member term, but so be it."}, {'account_id': 14394, 'date': '2016-05-11 12:04:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi afazekas, I just caught up with your previous review again.

If it is preferred that the term for a non privileged user be 'user' rather than 'member' then I am happy to make this change. It is wider in scope than the intent of patch, but if we can be clearer and more consistent with the name, I'm all for it.

My naming is based around the role names 'Member' and '_member_', but the parameters created here are not specifically related to these roles in particular, it is really the role of a non-privileged user being defined with a default of Member to match other parts of tempest.

Shall I make the change?"}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2016-05-11 13:10:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I see the problem that you're trying to solve, but I'm not convinced we need an extra configuration option.
Dynamic credential providers uses two things:
- tempest_roles config option, which is the list of all roles to be assigned to users created on the fly
- Member which is the hardcoded role which is added it tempest_roles is empty, to make sure at least one role is assigned

Pre provisioned accounts could work the same:
- expect tempest_roles for primary and alt users
- else expect 'Member' if nothing is configured there"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-05-24 09:11:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 14394, 'date': '2016-05-24 11:25:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2016-05-24 11:42:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

It looks like this has been rebased but there's no reply to my comments on PS4, so re-posting my -1."}, {'account_id': 14394, 'date': '2016-05-24 11:43:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(note: patchset 5 is just a rebase)

Andrea, I agree it would be nicer(and make a two line patchset!) if there was not an extra configuration item, and it's really up to the Tempest project if hardcoding role names is the way to go; I'll change it if Tempest requires this for the patchset.

Both _member_ and Member are used interchangeably between OpenStack projects, so I'm not sure it's the best thing to hardcode, but it does save on extra configuration clutter.

Could the same hardcode logic could be applied for the 'admin_role' configuration item? This role seems more consistent cross project than Member."}, {'account_id': 14394, 'date': '2016-05-24 12:09:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Discussed on IRC with andreaf, I will change this patchset to use the existing tempest_roles configuration option for the case where the test does not define any required user roles.

This will mean no additional options required and a list of roles will be supported.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-05-24 13:07:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

commit_message:
tempest_roles now used as default roles for preprov_creds.

Allows preprov_creds to request primary and alt accounts using
a named role, rather than simply any non-admin account if a test
does not explicitly request a set of roles.

Change-Id: Ia8d4b18192e09c6abf95bd0fe5a34d640b66336a
Closes-Bug: 1565584

commit_message:
[WIP] Fix a bug of default_domain_id

When I use tempest verify-config, the console show me a 404 error(
I can not get the default domain). So I thought we need add the
default_domain_id in create_project() and create_user().

Closes-Bug: #1711891

Change-Id: I894ed29bd0a7d134c0619c05585b03e1ef228cf2

subject: Cut cinder backend name from host info
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1736, 'name': 'Ivan Kolodyazhny', 'email': 'e0ne@e0ne.info', 'username': 'e0ne'}, {'_account_id': 5689, 'name': 'Masayuki Igawa', 'email': 'masayuki@igawa.io', 'username': 'igawa'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 12033, 'name': 'DellEMC XtremIO CI', 'email': 'emc.xio.ci@emc.com', 'username': 'emc-xio-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 15232, 'name': 'Leontii', 'email': 'listomin@mirantis.com', 'username': 'listomin'}, {'_account_id': 20190, 'name': 'zhufl', 'email': 'zhu.fanglei@zte.com.cn', 'username': 'zhufl'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27190, 'name': 'Leopard Ma', 'email': 'mabao@inspur.com', 'username': 'LeopardMa'}]

[{'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-26 12:07:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2017-11-27 03:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the updating, could you put more details about why we should remove the backend info from host, and otherwise what would happen?'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-27 08:56:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-27 09:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Thanks for the updating, could you put more details about why we
 > should remove the backend info from host, and otherwise what would
 > happen?

Created a link on launchpad and added the link. In short as I understand "_get_host" function should return hostname. But we get <host name>#<backand name> therefore can't match a host with cinder-volume service and a host where a volume was created. Therefore we need to convert a value of "os-vol-host-attr:host" to just hostname. Please give me know if you need some info and thanks for quick reacting on the commit ;)'}, {'account_id': 27190, 'date': '2017-11-27 12:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2017-11-28 09:07:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Hi! Thank you for the patch. I left some nitpick comments. But my main concern is there's no information about '#' in the api docs. (I couldn't find it at least.) I guess, this patch is correct, but I'd like to know the specification of Cinder. So, I'd like to wait cinder guy's comments."}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:29:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:56:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 11:33:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2017-11-29 11:34:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

LGTM from cinder point of view'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 11:41:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@masayuki@igawa.io As explaned here [1] hostnames in Cinder in the following format:
Host@Backend#Pool
[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/utils.py#L690'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-11-29 15:23:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-12-01 09:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 20190, 'date': '2017-12-05 08:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> @masayuki@igawa.io As explaned here [1] hostnames in Cinder in the
 > following format:
 > Host@Backend#Pool
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/utils.py#L690

If the format is "Host@Backend#Pool", then why you get "<host name>#<backend name>" in the output of 
"openstack volume show -f value -c os-vol-host-attr:host <volume>" command?
It should be something like "cinder@lvm#lvm" which follows "Host@Backend#Pool"'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2017-12-07 04:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Yeah, it looks weird.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2017-12-08 03:16:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

it handle all the cases so fix looks ok to me. But zhufl has point here.

@Ivan- can backend name be missing when pool is present in host name? for e.x. host#pool'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2017-12-08 03:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Also it is helpful for user if cinder doc tells about this format clearly.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-12-11 15:10:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 15232, 'date': '2017-12-11 15:13:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Ivan's comment is valid. Please check this comment on launchpad https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1734636/comments/3"}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2017-12-12 02:52:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Thank you for updating! But I don't still understand yet. When we get 'ctl01#DEFAULT' value? I think it's good to mention about it, at least. And the current cinder implementation, if we don't specified 'enabled_backends', it's a configuration error not warning[0]. So, I'm not sure we should care about the misconfiguration of cinder volume. Any thoughts?

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/cmd/volume.py#L84"}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2021-02-09 10:30:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandon as the related review got to Invalid state ~2 years ago, see https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1734636'}]

commit_message:
Cut cinder backend name from host info

  Cinder can have hostname with 'host@backend#pool' format where pool
  info can be present on hostname string.
  To handle all cases we need to extract the hostname string as per
  above formatrmat.

Closes-Bug: #1734636
Change-Id: If50b82a48e7449f41f8fb08f63232eb9a21c2cf5

commit_message:
test_create_token support unspecified user fields

v2.test_tokens.TokensTest.test_create_token would fail if the
user ID (or other account field) wasn't specified in
accounts.yaml because creds.user_id (for example) winds up
being None whereas the ID in the token is whatever the server
returns and so doesn't match None.

The proposed fix is, if there's no creds.user_id (etc.)
specified in the accounts.yaml, then only require that it's in
the returned token and don't test the value.

Change-Id: I56921d3a4a6c94fa3f0c4879079131e6f5da933c
Closes-Bug: 1635043

commit_message:
[Unity]: Fix failback issue of multiple volumes

Fix bug 1894176 to make sure host could be failback
successfully if there is more than one volume enable
replication.

Change-Id: Ib1acc8bcfcdd0d6fa92a91690dffea389fc73ba1
Closes-bug: #1894176

subject: Increase timeout value of heat stack creation

commit_message:
Increase timeout value of heat stack creation

Sometimes tacker-functional-devstack-multinode-sol-separated-nfvo
fails because of timeout of heat stack creation.

This patch increases timeout value of heat stack creation.

Change-Id: I825a60ac2261c8d47ca4273318f51221be36bb9e

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-05 20:11:38.000000000', 'message': 'Make import wait check for store status

During a glance import, if we fail, we are not going to change the
state of the image in all cases, and definitely not to 'active'.
Thus waiting for active just means we keep polling a broken image
for a long time, wasting resources. We should also be checking the
list of failed stores, and if something pops in there, abort right
then and there.

This adds that different poll loop for the basic import tests of
web-download and glance-direct.

Note that I'm doing this because sometimes web-download fails in the
gate due to a timeout trying to pull our http_image and we just keep
looping until our own timeout instead of noticing. It also means
we just report "never reached active state" instead of what we know
to be true, which is that import failed.

Change-Id: Ie0569b84dd1c397a79d13af609bf23db52a2dfc8

then and there.

This patch makes us use the wait_for_image_imported_to_stores()
waiter, and modifies it to not look at image['stores'] if no
stores are provided. In the case where we don't have multistore

until we time out, but otherwise we will (barring a glance bug for
which I also have a fix).

During a glance import, if we fail, we are not going to change the
state of the image in all cases, and definitely not to 'active'.

for a long time, wasting resources. We should also be checking the

This patch makes us use the wait_for_image_imported_to_stores()

support enabled, we won't be able to know that the import failed
until we time out, but otherwise we will (barring a glance bug for
which I also have a fix). This also makes the waiter not fail on
KeyError if os_glance_failed_import is not present on the image,
as would be the case if used when stores are not enabled.

Note that I'm doing this because sometimes web-download fails in the
gate due to a timeout trying to pull our http_image and we just keep
looping until our own timeout instead of noticing. It also means

Change-Id: Ie0569b84dd1c397a79d13af609bf23db52a2dfc8

commit_message:
Make import wait check for store status

During a glance import, if we fail, we are not going to change the
state of the image in all cases, and definitely not to 'active'.
Thus waiting for active just means we keep polling a broken image
for a long time, wasting resources. We should also be checking the
list of failed stores, and if something pops in there, abort right
then and there.

This patch makes us use the wait_for_image_imported_to_stores()
waiter, and modifies it to not look at image['stores'] if no
stores are provided. In the case where we don't have multistore
support enabled, we won't be able to know that the import failed
until we time out, but otherwise we will (barring a glance bug for
which I also have a fix). This also makes the waiter not fail on
KeyError if os_glance_failed_import is not present on the image,
as would be the case if used when stores are not enabled.

Note that I'm doing this because sometimes web-download fails in the
gate due to a timeout trying to pull our http_image and we just keep
looping until our own timeout instead of noticing. It also means
we just report "never reached active state" instead of what we know
to be true, which is that import failed.

Change-Id: Ie0569b84dd1c397a79d13af609bf23db52a2dfc8

commit_message:
Also cap pip in tempest tox venv

I am still unable to stack because of pip 20.3, but this time
because of the tempest venv build. This forces it to the same
capped pip, which further works around the problem.

Change-Id: Icfaaefe1aa576733764b393cba96d276c9b1cf68
Related-Bug: #1906367
(cherry picked from commit bcd0acf6c0b5d6501e91133c3a937b3fc40f7122)

commit_message:
[WIP] Add support for using NVMe specific cleaning

This change adds support for utilising NVMe specific cleaning tools
on supported devices. This will remove the neccessity of using shred to
securely delete the contents of a NVMe drive and enable using nvme-cli
tools instead, improving cleaning performance and reducing wear on the device.

Story: 2008290
Change-Id: I9c6ee475601e8169fa46fccc6717a197af210068

commit_message:
Add a read-only role to keystoneauth

An idea was floated recently of a read-only role that can be used for
cluster-wide audits, and is otherwise safe. It was also included into
the "Consistent and Secure Default Policies" effort in OpenStack,
where it implements "reader" personas in system, domain, and project
scopes. This patch implements it for system scope, where it's most
useful for operators.

Change-Id: I5f5fff2e61a3e5fb4f4464262a8ea558a6e7d7ef

commit_message:
Set tosca.nodes.BlockStorage size required as false

We can provide already created volume_id for tosca.nodes.BlockStorage,
in that case no new volume will be created, and no size required.

Implements: blueprint attach-existing-volume

Change-Id: I35452efb333f7abdb6b7200531e94542fc3877c0

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4149, 'date': '2020-09-23 23:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 32102, 'date': '2020-09-28 04:09:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have a query regarding the proposed design.
As per TOSCA documentation for Block Storage [1], the "Properties" section describe in "5.9.11 tosca.nodes.Storage.BlockStorage".
Regarding "size" and "volume id" property.
Definition:
  "size" property: The requested storage size (default unit is MB). Required when an existing volume (i.e., volume_id) is not available. If volume_id is provided, size is ignored. Resize of existing volumes is not considered at this time.

But it seems "size" property is mandatory in Tacker.
On an attempt to attach existing volume using proposed patch failed with following error.
stack@devstack18:~/devstack$ openstack vnf descriptor create --vnfd-file sample-tosca-vnfd-existing-block-storage_new.yaml PresistBlockVNFD
tosca-parser failed: -
The pre-parsed input failed validation with the following error(s):

        MissingRequiredFieldError: "properties" of template "VB1" is missing required field "['size']".

Although adding "size" property to TOSCA template resolve the error.

Could you please help me in understand whether this is an expected behavior or there is some gap in design.

References:
[1]: http://docs.oasis-open.org/tosca/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML/v1.2/csprd01/TOSCA-Simple-Profile-YAML-v1.2-csprd01.html'}, {'account_id': 4149, 'date': '2020-09-28 04:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Manpreet,
Did you try this patch with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698439/2 (whish is a parent of this patch) ?'}, {'account_id': 32102, 'date': '2020-09-28 14:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Hi Manpreet,
 > Did you try this patch with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698439/2
 > (whish is a parent of this patch) ?

Thank you Itsuro Oda for your suggestion. With this patch, the error does resolve.'}, {'account_id': 32102, 'date': '2020-10-08 12:28:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Findings regarding tosca.nodes.BlockStorage "size" property. 
In order to set tosca.nodes.BlockStorage "size" required as false, 
this can be simply achieve by adding definition in 
"tacker/tosca/lib/tacker_nfv_defs.yaml".
    tosca.nodes.BlockStorage.Tacker:
      . . . 
       image:
         type: string
         required: false
+      size:
+        type: scalar-unit.size
+        required: false
+        constraints:
+          - greater_or_equal: 1 MB
+
This resolves the issue address by me in the previous comment.
IMO master patch could be drop as it alters toscaparser/elements/TOSCA_definition_1_0.yaml.'}, {'account_id': 32102, 'date': '2020-10-08 12:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

A follow-up comment to the patch I pasted in the comment on Sep 23 7:25PM: the original code seems to assume that if the first volume entry does not specify 'volume_id', all the subsequent entries must never do so as well. I have no idea whether there is a spec to support the assumption. If anyone knows, please point me in the right direction."}, {'account_id': 32395, 'date': '2020-10-28 06:16:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 25701, 'date': '2020-11-16 02:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25701, 'date': '2020-11-16 05:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25701, 'date': '2020-11-24 06:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 31821, 'date': '2020-11-24 20:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Removed broken mocked params

When building local packages the local params will now assume
certificate information that is otherwise irrelevant to the
test. Because the underlying functions have changed, there's
no need to continue with these asserts, so they've been removed.

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iaca5c8e149e28dfa7d4862c1b9ac13b8658fa006

commit_message:
Remove duplication of getting HOT templates

Previously get_base_nest_hot_dict() was called by vnflcm_driver
and openstack infra_driver redundantly.

This patch remove calling get_base_nest_hot_dict() from
vnflcm_driver because HOT is openstack specific.
base_hot_dict parameter of infra_driver interface is removed
at the same time.
Note that vnf_package_path parameter is passed to infra_driver
always since it is used by both openstack and kubernetes.

Change-Id: I94fc914f58747ae75651480ec11b177140fa849a

commit_message:
Workaround for the ControllerRevision FT

This patch is provisional workaround for bug [1].

I think possible ways to fix the bug are using the kubernetes
python client v11.0.0. However, as a other issue, the
ControllerRevision resources is not delete and remain. The
problem of resources remaining cannot be solved immediately.
Therefore, add a skip decorator to skip the Functional Test of
ControllerRevision as a workaround.

The added skip decorator will be removed after this issue
completely resolved.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tacker/+bug/1910327

Partial-Bug: #1910327
Change-Id: I6bedc5c8c712c9cf7d95ae5cb7384c4dea187108

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-01 05:16:21.000000000', 'message': 'Close HOT template files after read

Previously get_base_nest_hot_dict() used by tacker-conductor
opens and reads HOT template files but does not close them.
As a result, tacker-conductor will reach the limit of open
file descriptor while it is running long time.

This patch fixes to close HOT template files after read
them.

This patch makes some clean-ups too.
* use existing method to make path construction and make it easy to
  understand.
* remove _get_base_hot_dict() because it was replaced to
  get_base_nest_hot_dict() and is not used anywhere now.
  And it is considerd that it will not be used any more.
* remove meaningless array to tupple translation.
* same bug fix and clean-ups are applied in the same file.

Closes-Bug: #1913978

Change-Id: I6ffdadc196cf2ddcec3625c6bd99b5133e37af4b
'}]
commit_message:
Close HOT template files after read

Previously get_base_nest_hot_dict() used by tacker-conductor
opens and reads HOT template files but does not close them.
As a result, tacker-conductor will reach the limit of open
file descriptor while it is running long time.

This patch fixes to close HOT template files after read
them.

This patch makes some clean-ups too.
* use existing method to make path construction and make it easy to
  understand.
* remove _get_base_hot_dict() because it was replaced to
  get_base_nest_hot_dict() and is not used anywhere now.
  And it is considerd that it will not be used any more.
* remove meaningless array to tupple translation.
* same bug fix and clean-ups are applied in the same file.

Closes-Bug: #1913978

Change-Id: I6ffdadc196cf2ddcec3625c6bd99b5133e37af4b

commit_message:
Bump oslo.policy version to 2.1.0

The secure RBAC work requires the of oslo.policy's scope_types argument,
which was made available in 1.32.0. This commit updates to version 2.1.0
so that we're using something more relevant.

Required oslo.context bump.

Change-Id: I48e8882f629886d1b8abadff6e60aad91d1169c7

commit_message:
Bump oslo.log version to 4.3.0

This allows us to use the Wallaby release marker in versionutils for
deprecations.

Required some other bumps to satisfy lower-constraints.

commit_message:
Setup OpenInfra Channels

openstack-forum, openstack-ptg, openstack-summit and openinfra-summit
will now be openinfra-events.

openstack-diversity will now be openinfra-diversity.

openstack-foundation will now be openinfra.

openstack-board will come later after we can get op rights and
register the channel.

Change-Id: I4d09979e0c9dac75c7f3d878cde99cdc56b8dbe3

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-28 17:00:37.000000000', 'message': 'Add service ordering to cleanup service to avoid conflicts with agent startup

If the port cleanup takes too long, the neutron agents might begin
operations on the ovs bridges while cleanup is still ongoing. This can
cause undefined behavior and errors in the agent.

Change-Id: Ia0e31c9469033c50a8b65af7fee1adf03b22d4c2
Closes-Bug: #1913623
'}]
commit_message:
Add service ordering to cleanup service to avoid conflicts with agent startup

If the port cleanup takes too long, the neutron agents might begin
operations on the ovs bridges while cleanup is still ongoing. This can
cause undefined behavior and errors in the agent.

Change-Id: Ia0e31c9469033c50a8b65af7fee1adf03b22d4c2
Closes-Bug: #1913623

commit_message:
Permit to bind object-server on replication_port

Add a new configuration option 'servers_per_port_type' to choose on which
port the object-server must bind when servers_per_port is enabled. It can
be 'port' (the default, which does not change the current behavior), or
'replication_port', or both separated by a comma.

The following configuration will create two workers per device if port
and replication_port are different in the ring. One worker for clients'
traffic and one worker for replication traffic:
    servers_per_port = 1
    servers_per_port_type = port, replication_port

If using different ports in the ring for proxy and replication traffic,
it allows to dedicate processes to replication, which can be
IO-intensive and sometime hangs the process for many seconds.

Closes-Bug: #1669579

Change-Id: I991806227f18f115646b0549a77326617aa2c8fe

commit_message:
Add --disable-container-prepare flag

Users may want to skip the container prepare process to ensure they
don't update their containers. This change adds a
--disable-container-prepare flag to the following actions which should
skip the preparation actions.
 - overcloud deploy (and updates)
 - overcloud plan actions
 - undercloud deploy (and upgrades)
 - tripleo deploy (and standalone deploy)

Conflicts:
        tripleoclient/tests/v1/test_overcloud_plan.py
        tripleoclient/tests/workflows/test_plan_management.py
        tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py
        tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_plan.py
        tripleoclient/workflows/plan_management.py

Closes-Bug: #1896757
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/769774
Change-Id: I30b448930f53aef108d9bdb544a6d02b18658b0d
(cherry picked from commit 0d84ac9234bf93ca4d1471d5860739bc31a6be80)

commit_message:
Split network validation to it's own play

When we moved the network deployment to free, we can hit a race
condition where some nodes are being configured prior to the controllers
being ready. This can lead to the basic network validation failing.  We
can deal with this by moving the validation to it's own play so that we
ensure all network configurations have occurred prior to to checking
that nodes can ping the controllers.

Change-Id: I48665379a87e701633be1bcc90bd8be1cc75c513
Closes-Bug: #1913725
(cherry picked from commit 64e735898b8fae7643fc092fed840d867a252046)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-02-05 07:47:21.000000000', 'message': '[devstack] Setup a "shared-file-system" service

A few releases ago, service types were standardized
across OpenStack [1] and manila's service type was
recommended as "shared-file-system" [2]. Tools were
meant to look at the service-types-authority [3]
and os-service-types repository [4] to find a list
of standard service type names for various first
party OpenStack services.

The openstacksdk currently relies on the service
type to be "shared-file-system" [5], so let's set
one up in devstack, to aid contributors working on
openstacksdk.

It is desirable to have all clients to initially
look for the standard service type name in the
cloud's service catalog, and fall back to the
legacy name ("sharev2") in environments that
call the v2 API that.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/service-types-authority/
[2] https://service-types.openstack.org/service-types.json
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/service-types-authority
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/os-service-types
[5] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/commit/f4dd6fe5fd21fb866b43330ecbbafee5cf553ded/openstack/_services_mixin.py#L71-L72

Change-Id: I6a1ada102a40f3e83fe8e5287856d01dd137ea95
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
[devstack] Setup a "shared-file-system" service

A few releases ago, service types were standardized
across OpenStack [1] and manila's service type was
recommended as "shared-file-system" [2]. Tools were
meant to look at the service-types-authority [3]
and os-service-types repository [4] to find a list
of standard service type names for various first
party OpenStack services.

The openstacksdk currently relies on the service
type to be "shared-file-system" [5], so let's set
one up in devstack, to aid contributors working on
openstacksdk.

It is desirable to have all clients to initially
look for the standard service type name in the
cloud's service catalog, and fall back to the
legacy name ("sharev2") in environments that
call the v2 API that.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/service-types-authority/
[2] https://service-types.openstack.org/service-types.json
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/service-types-authority
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/os-service-types
[5] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/commit/f4dd6fe5fd21fb866b43330ecbbafee5cf553ded/openstack/_services_mixin.py#L71-L72

Change-Id: I6a1ada102a40f3e83fe8e5287856d01dd137ea95
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Enable healthcheck middleware

This change makes healtcheck middleware enabled by default, so that
operators can use the middleware to monitor service availability for
various purpose like healthcheck by load balancers.

Change-Id: I47e65d23ebfe310643896e1de3396cd627a3def3

commit_message:
feat(tls) [WIP] Add tls feature gate to openstack-helm-infra

This will serve as a feature gate for the openstack-helm-infra
repo by turning on tls for the included charts. When tls is
added to a chart a job will need to be added here to turn the
tls on and test that the chart will still deploy correctly.

Change-Id: I13506ef0b3979004b2be1aa0f46a23d5cb78d065

commit_message:
fup: Merge duplicate volume attachment checks

This is a follow up to I2881d77d52bcbde9f3ac6a6ddfb4a22a9bd45c8a where
it was noted that we could merge these checks into one using a single db
query for all active volume attachments for a given volume. This
requires changes to the BlockDeviceMappingList object and was thus left
as a separate change to allow the original to be backported.

Change-Id: I859be652eb8fff591899a223193bd9efc8830cf3

The code does what the commit message says. So I'm +2

I'm still wondering if we now remove a possibility that the admin actively used. E.g. some kind of recovery procedure where the volume is attached to check the consistency of the content while the original instance is on a failed compute host. Anyhow we will see via bug report if we broke some admin use case"}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2021-02-04 18:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

(2 comments)

Looks sensible to me. I note gibi's mention on whether this could break some sort of admin recovery-for-failed-compute-node procedure and agree we can wait and see if anyone reports anything.

I would tend to think this check and avoidance of multiattachment of non multiattach volumes is worth the loss of such a recovery procedure, if one exists."}]

[{'created': '2020-12-24 13:28:53.000000000', 'message': 'api: Reject volume attach requests when an active bdm exists

When attaching volumes to instances Nova has previously relied on checks
carried out by c-api to ensure that a single non-multiattach volume is
not attached to multiple instances at once. While this works well in
most cases it does not handle PEBKAC issues when admins reset the state
of a volume to available, allowing users to request that Nova attach the
volume to another instance.

This change aims to address this by including a simple check in the
attach flow for non-multiattach volumes ensuring that there are no
existing active block device mapping records for the volume already
present within Nova.

Closes-Bug: #1908075
Change-Id: I2881d77d52bcbde9f3ac6a6ddfb4a22a9bd45c8a

commit_message:
api: Reject volume attach requests when an active bdm exists

When attaching volumes to instances Nova has previously relied on checks
carried out by c-api to ensure that a single non-multiattach volume is
not attached to multiple instances at once. While this works well in
most cases it does not handle PEBKAC issues when admins reset the state
of a volume to available, allowing users to request that Nova attach the
volume to another instance.

This change aims to address this by including a simple check in the
attach flow for non-multiattach volumes ensuring that there are no
existing active block device mapping records for the volume already
present within Nova.

Closes-Bug: #1908075
Change-Id: I2881d77d52bcbde9f3ac6a6ddfb4a22a9bd45c8a

commit_message:
Check existence of expires_in for auth

If a registries doesn't provide an expires_in with their token, the
current code fails doing the comparison. If no such header is included,
let's assume there is no expire time so we can just use the cached
token.  If the token expires, we'll reauth as usual.

Change-Id: I96ab407ba50e2183141daec3341dbb29545d5beb
Closes-Bug: #1912645
(cherry picked from commit e04774948e8cfa8ac4d2a1f57f0e53e2ef0861ee)

[{'created': '2021-01-19 09:54:36.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Set source IPv4 address from inventory vars

Currently users have to pass in a dictionary of HOSTNAME:SOURCE_IPV4 of
all nodes in the deployment. An example is as follows from THT:

  FrrBgpIpv4LoopbackMap:
    ctrl-1-0: 99.99.1.1
    ctrl-2-0: 99.99.2.1
    ctrl-3-0: 99.99.3.1
    cmp-1-0: 99.99.1.2
    cmp-2-0: 99.99.2.2
    cmp-3-0: 99.99.3.2
    cmp-1-1: 99.99.1.3
    cmp-2-1: 99.99.2.3
    cmp-3-1: 99.99.3.3

This is rather time consuming, prone to typos and requires updating at
node scale up/down. It would be much easier if users could just pass in
the network and have tripleo_frr get the IP from given network.
Snip from tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml:

  ControllerRack1:
    hosts:
      ctrl-1-0: {ansible_host: 192.168.1.101, canonical_hostname: ctrl-1-0.bgp.ftw,
        main_network_hostname: ctrl-1-0.mainnetwork.bgp.ftw, main_network_ip: 99.99.1.1,
        [...]

commit_message:
Set source IPv4 address from inventory vars

Currently users have to pass in a dictionary of HOSTNAME:SOURCE_IPV4 of
all nodes in the deployment. An example is as follows from THT:

  FrrBgpIpv4LoopbackMap:
    ctrl-1-0: 99.99.1.1
    ctrl-2-0: 99.99.2.1
    ctrl-3-0: 99.99.3.1
    cmp-1-0: 99.99.1.2
    cmp-2-0: 99.99.2.2
    cmp-3-0: 99.99.3.2
    cmp-1-1: 99.99.1.3
    cmp-2-1: 99.99.2.3
    cmp-3-1: 99.99.3.3

This is rather time consuming, prone to typos and requires updating at
node scale up/down. It would be much easier if users could just pass in
the network and have tripleo_frr get the IP from given network.
Snip from tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml:

  ControllerRack1:
    hosts:
      ctrl-1-0: {ansible_host: 192.168.1.101, canonical_hostname: ctrl-1-0.bgp.ftw,
        main_network_hostname: ctrl-1-0.mainnetwork.bgp.ftw, main_network_ip: 99.99.1.1,
        [...]

Change-Id: I43852cb3570b8cb12a35f4bc641a42ddfd8ad7f1

commit_message:
[Validator Show Run] Display simplified results by default

This patch is displaying the content of the validation_output dictionary
which is a simplified output content (the former validation_output)
instead of dumping the entire log file in the stdout.

It also fixes the --full argument which was True forever!

Change-Id: Id94132d23d272d383b65a839a75b08f855fb6be3
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4229bee94016ad5a78dd8455f282a8e7f4a3d28e)
(cherry picked from commit 7873e6d800d75119730c7cd8ff1152fe08aa1c49)
(cherry picked from commit 0f91bcce72633ef9f1e006460aca8ce1c3dec83a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-01-15 16:59:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix --limit with commas

Kayobe allows specifying a --limit argument, which is passed through to
Ansible. In some cases we wish to add an intersection with a group. This
allows us to reuse playbooks for the seed, overcloud etc.

For example, the lvm.yml playbook specifies a host list of
seed-hypervisor:seed:overcloud. When executed as part of a kayobe
overcloud host configure command, Kayobe passes a limit of overcloud. If
the user specifies a --limit argument, this gets intersected with the
overcloud limit: host1:&overcloud.

The problem happens if the user specifies multiple parts to the host
pattern in their limit using a comma, e.g. host1,host2. This results in
host1,host2:&overcloud. Ansible ignores the colon, and treats this as
host1 or host2:&overcloud.

The solution is to use a comma to join the patterns if the user has used
a comma: host1,host2,&overcloud

Change-Id: Ibe42fa372c6fa0c539d2c2b0e238601286dc213d
Story: 2008255
Task: 41111
(cherry picked from commit 017b092df70706177c542c3a3cab3f9d0a75e5c2)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix --limit with commas

Kayobe allows specifying a --limit argument, which is passed through to
Ansible. In some cases we wish to add an intersection with a group. This
allows us to reuse playbooks for the seed, overcloud etc.

For example, the lvm.yml playbook specifies a host list of
seed-hypervisor:seed:overcloud. When executed as part of a kayobe
overcloud host configure command, Kayobe passes a limit of overcloud. If
the user specifies a --limit argument, this gets intersected with the
overcloud limit: host1:&overcloud.

The problem happens if the user specifies multiple parts to the host
pattern in their limit using a comma, e.g. host1,host2. This results in
host1,host2:&overcloud. Ansible ignores the colon, and treats this as
host1 or host2:&overcloud.

The solution is to use a comma to join the patterns if the user has used
a comma: host1,host2,&overcloud

Change-Id: Ibe42fa372c6fa0c539d2c2b0e238601286dc213d
Story: 2008255
Task: 41111
(cherry picked from commit 017b092df70706177c542c3a3cab3f9d0a75e5c2)
